_exec_summary.SummaryText:
2.1   Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Safety at DHL/KLS is inherent in the manner in which anhydrous ammonia is handled. While the design of the facility incorporates multiple safety devices, safe handling procedures, maintaining mechanical integrity, and appropriate training of our personnel are key aspects of safety at our facility.
DHL/KLS has implemented a process safety management (PSM) program that complies with the regulations stipulated by 29 CFR 1910.119, which requires DHL/KLS to implement integrated safeguards to prevent an ammonia release. A crucial component of this plan is the emergency action plan, developed in compliance with the emergency planning provisions of 29 CFR 1910.38. The emergency action plan includes pre-emergency planning and coordination with outside parties to enable coordinated action to effectively deal with unplanned events.
2.2   Facility Description and Substances Handled
DHL/KLS is a cold storage facility that stores and distributes produce. Cold storage requires the use of a refrigeration system to preserve the integrity of foods, and DHL/KLS uses ammonia as the refrigerant. Access to the facility is limited to authorized employees, management personnel, and contractors.
2.3   General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
DHL/KLS's written PSM plan incorporates many policies and procedures to ensure the safe operation and maintenance of the refrigeration equipment. Plan elements essential to the safe operation of the refrigeration system include employee participation, process safety information, process hazard analysis (PHA), operating procedures, training, contractor safety, pre-startup safety review, mechanical integrity, management of change, hot-work permits, incident investigation, emergency response and planning, and compliance audits. This plan will be reviewed annually, audited every three years, and updated as necessary by DHL/KLS.
Training is provide

d to ensure that each employee involved in operating the refrigeration system understands the refrigeration process, the operating procedures, and safety considerations. Only qualified maintenance personnel operate the refrigeration system.
2.4   Five-Year Accident History
There have been no reportable accidents at the DHL/KLS facility in the past five years.
2.5   Emergency Planning and Response
DHL/KLS has a written emergency action plan to ensure that precautions and procedures are in place to protect employee and public health and safety during a chemical emergency. It complies with the provisions of 29 CFR 1910.38. The emergency action plan includes pre-emergency planning and coordinating with outside parties. This enables those who deal with emergencies to have a course of action to effectively deal with unplanned events. This plan has been provided to and reviewed with  Romulus Fire Department.
The approach in the development of this plan has been to identify the ammonia emergencies most likely to occur at DHL/KLS and to establish precautions and procedures to protect life, safety, and health during an emergency. The refrigeration process has backup prevention systems to keep processing malfunctions from becoming ammonia-release emergencies. If an emergency does occur, DHL/KLS has trained personnel to immediately notify the Romulus Fire Department and take actions to mitigate incidental releases but will immediately call the fire department and evacuate if the release is determined to be uncontrolled. Automatic alarms, shutdown systems, and controls have been designed to minimize the potential for an uncontrolled release.
All DHL/KLS personnel are trained to fulfill their designated responsibilities in an emergency. Mock emergency drills are held periodically to maintain familiarity with response actions and identify plan elements requiring improvement.
This plan shall be reviewed annually and updated as necessary.
2.6   Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Any

upgrades or extensive maintenance work performed in the future will comply with codes and standards applicable at that time.

DHL/KLS completed a process hazard analysis in September 2023. Higher priority items are scheduled for completion by 12/31/2024. Lower-priority items are scheduled for completion by September 2025. DHL/KLS will track assigned target dates and the completion status of all PHA recommendations to ensure items are addressed promptly.
